108 /*!
109 @brief Helper to determine whether there's a key_type for T.
110 @sa http://stackoverflow.com/a/7728728/266378
111 */
112 template<typename T>
113 struct has_mapped_type
114 {
115  private:
116  template<typename C> static char test(typename C::mapped_type*);
117  template<typename C> static int test(...);
118  public:
119  enum { value = sizeof(test<T>(0)) == sizeof(char) };
120 };
121 
122 /// "equality" comparison for floating point numbers
123 template<typename T>
124 static bool approx(const T a, const T b)
125 {
126  return not (a > b or a < b);
127 }
128 
129 /// Is type T safe for a numeric_limits template parameter?
130 template<typename T> using isNlSafe = std::is_convertible<T, T>;
131 
132 /// Is type T an integer type?
133 template<typename T, bool = isNlSafe<T>::value> struct IsInt;
134 
135 template<typename T > struct IsInt<T, true>
136 {
137  static const bool value = std::conditional<std::numeric_limits<T>::is_integer, std::true_type, std::false_type>::type::value;
138 };
139 
140 template<typename T > struct IsInt<T, false>
141 {
142  static const bool value = false;
143 };
144 }

146 // Forward declarations:
147 template <
148  template<typename U, typename V, typename... Args> class ObjectType = std::map,
149  template<typename U, typename... Args> class ArrayType = std::vector,
150  class StringType = std::string,
151  class BooleanType = bool,
152  class NumberIntegerType = int64_t,
153  class NumberFloatType = double,
154  template<typename U> class AllocatorType = std::allocator
155  >
156 class basic_json;

158 using json = basic_json<>;
159 
160 template<typename T, typename Dummy = int> struct JsonConvert;
161 
162 template<typename T, typename J = json> struct JsonTraits
163 {
164  private:
165  template<typename U>
166  static auto testMember(int) -> decltype(std::declval<U>().toJson(), std::true_type());
167  template<typename> static std::false_type testMember(...);
168  using HasMember = decltype(testMember<T>(0));
169 
170  template<typename U>
171  static auto testJsonConvert(int) -> decltype(JsonConvert<U>::toJson(std::declval<U>()), std::true_type());
172  template<typename> static std::false_type testJsonConvert(...);
173  using HasJsonConvert = decltype(testJsonConvert<T>(0));
174  public:
175  constexpr static bool hasMember = std::is_same<HasMember, std::true_type>::value;
176  constexpr static bool hasUser = hasMember || std::is_same<HasJsonConvert, std::true_type>::value;
177 };
178 
179 /// @brief Provide a default class conversion if a toJson() member function exists.
180 template<typename T> struct JsonConvert<T, typename std::enable_if<JsonTraits<T>::hasMember, int>::type>
181 {
182  static auto toJson(const T& t) -> decltype(std::declval<T>().toJson()) const {return t.toJson();}
183 };

185 /*!
186 @brief a class to store JSON values
187 
188 @tparam ObjectType type for JSON objects (@c std::map by default; will be used
189 in @ref object_t)
190 @tparam ArrayType type for JSON arrays (@c std::vector by default; will be used
191 in @ref array_t)
192 @tparam StringType type for JSON strings and object keys (@c std::string by
193 default; will be used in @ref string_t)
194 @tparam BooleanType type for JSON booleans (@c `bool` by default; will be used
195 in @ref boolean_t)
196 @tparam NumberIntegerType type for JSON integer numbers (@c `int64_t` by
197 default; will be used in @ref number_integer_t)
198 @tparam NumberFloatType type for JSON floating-point numbers (@c `double` by
199 default; will be used in @ref number_float_t)
200 @tparam AllocatorType type of the allocator to use (@c `std::allocator` by
201 default)
202 
203 @requirement The class satisfies the following concept requirements:
204 - Basic
205  - [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible):
206  JSON values can be default constructed. The result will be a JSON null value.
207  - [MoveConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveConstructible):
208  A JSON value can be constructed from an rvalue argument.
209  - [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible):
210  A JSON value can be copy-constrcuted from an lvalue expression.
211  - [MoveAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveAssignable):
212  A JSON value van be assigned from an rvalue argument.
213  - [CopyAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyAssignable):
214  A JSON value can be copy-assigned from an lvalue expression.
215  - [Destructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Destructible):
216  JSON values can be destructed.
217 - Layout
218  - [StandardLayoutType](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/StandardLayoutType):
219  JSON values have
220  [standard layout](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/data_members#Standard_layout):
221  All non-static data members are private and standard layout types, the class
222  has no virtual functions or (virtual) base classes.
223 - Library-wide
224  - [EqualityComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/EqualityComparable):
225  JSON values can be compared with `==`, see @ref
226  operator==(const_reference,const_reference).
227  - [LessThanComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/LessThanComparable):
228  JSON values can be compared with `<`, see @ref
229  operator<(const_reference,const_reference).
230  - [Swappable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Swappable):
231  Any JSON lvalue or rvalue of can be swapped with any lvalue or rvalue of
232  other compatible types, using unqualified function call @ref swap().
233  - [NullablePointer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/NullablePointer):
234  JSON values can be compared against `std::nullptr_t` objects which are used
235  to model the `null` value.
236 - Container
237  - [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container):
238  JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide iterator access.
239  - [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer);
240  JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide reverse iterator
241  access.
242 
243 @internal
244 @note ObjectType trick from http://stackoverflow.com/a/9860911
245 @endinternal
246 
247 @see RFC 7159 <http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159>
248 */
249 template <
250  template<typename U, typename V, typename... Args> class ObjectType,
251  template<typename U, typename... Args> class ArrayType,
252  class StringType,
253  class BooleanType,
254  class NumberIntegerType,
255  class NumberFloatType,
256  template<typename U> class AllocatorType
257  >
258 class basic_json
259 {
260  private:
261  /// workaround type for MSVC
262  using basic_json_t = basic_json<ObjectType,
263  ArrayType,
264  StringType,
265  BooleanType,
266  NumberIntegerType,
267  NumberFloatType,
268  AllocatorType>;
269 
270  public:
271 
272  /////////////////////
273  // container types //
274  /////////////////////
275 
276  /// @name container types
277  /// @{
278 
279  /// the type of elements in a basic_json container
280  using value_type = basic_json;
281 
282  /// the type of an element reference
283  using reference = value_type&;
284 
285  /// the type of an element const reference
286  using const_reference = const value_type&;
287 
288  /// a type to represent differences between iterators
289  using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
290 
291  /// a type to represent container sizes
292  using size_type = std::size_t;
293 
294  /// the allocator type
295  using allocator_type = AllocatorType<basic_json>;
296 
297  /// the type of an element pointer
298  using pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::pointer;
299  /// the type of an element const pointer
300  using const_pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::const_pointer;
301 
302  // forward declaration
303  template<typename Base> class json_reverse_iterator;
304 
305  /// an iterator for a basic_json container
306  class iterator;
307  /// a const iterator for a basic_json container
308  class const_iterator;
309  /// a reverse iterator for a basic_json container
310  using reverse_iterator = json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::iterator>;
311  /// a const reverse iterator for a basic_json container
312  using const_reverse_iterator = json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::const_iterator>;
313 
314  /// @}
315 
316 
317  /*!
318  @brief returns the allocator associated with the container
319  */
320  static allocator_type get_allocator()
321  {
322  return allocator_type();
323  }
324 
325 
326  ///////////////////////////
327  // JSON value data types //
328  ///////////////////////////
329 
330  /// @name JSON value data types
331  /// @{
332 
333  /*!
334  @brief a type for an object
335 
336  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON objects as follows:
337  > An object is an unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs,
338  > where a name is a string and a value is a string, number, boolean, null,
339  > object, or array.
340 
341  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters @a
342  ObjectType which chooses the container (e.g., `std::map` or
343  `std::unordered_map`), @a StringType which chooses the type of the keys or
344  names, and @a AllocatorType which chooses the allocator to use.
345 
346  #### Default type
347 
348  With the default values for @a ObjectType (`std::map`), @a StringType
349  (`std::string`), and @a AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default value
350  for @a object_t is:
351 
352  @code {.cpp}
353  std::map<
354  std::string, // key_type
355  basic_json, // value_type
356  std::less<std::string>, // key_compare
357  std::allocator<std::pair<const std::string, basic_json>> // allocator_type
358  >
359  @endcode
360 
361  #### Behavior
362 
363  The choice of @a object_t influences the behavior of the JSON class. With
364  the default type, objects have the following behavior:
365 
366  - When all names are unique, objects will be interoperable in the sense
367  that all software implementations receiving that object will agree on the
368  name-value mappings.
369  - When the names within an object are not unique, later stored name/value
370  pairs overwrite previously stored name/value pairs, leaving the used
371  names unique. For instance, `{"key": 1}` and `{"key": 2, "key": 1}` will
372  be treated as equal and both stored as `{"key": 1}`.
373  - Internally, name/value pairs are stored in lexicographical order of the
374  names. Objects will also be serialized (see @ref dump) in this order. For
375  instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be stored and
376  serialized as `{"a": 2, "b": 1}`.
377  - When comparing objects, the order of the name/value pairs is irrelevant.
378  This makes objects interoperable in the sense that they will not be
379  affected by these differences. For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and
380  `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be treated as equal.
381 
382  #### Limits
383 
384  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
385  > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
386 
387  In this class, the object's limit of nesting is not constraint explicitly.
388  However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
389  runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the @ref
390  max_size function of a JSON object.
391 
392  #### Storage
393 
394  Objects are stored as pointers in a `basic_json` type. That is, for any
395  access to object values, a pointer of type `object_t*` must be dereferenced.
396 
397  @sa array_t
398  */
399  using object_t = ObjectType<StringType,
400  basic_json,
401  std::less<StringType>,
402  AllocatorType<std::pair<const StringType,
403  basic_json>>>;
404 
405  /*!
406  @brief a type for an array
407 
408  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON arrays as follows:
409  > An array is an ordered sequence of zero or more values.
410 
411  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters @a
412  ArrayType which chooses the container (e.g., `std::vector` or `std::list`)
413  and @a AllocatorType which chooses the allocator to use.
414 
415  #### Default type
416 
417  With the default values for @a ArrayType (`std::vector`) and @a
418  AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default value for @a array_t is:
419 
420  @code {.cpp}
421  std::vector<
422  basic_json, // value_type
423  std::allocator<basic_json> // allocator_type
424  >
425  @endcode
426 
427  #### Limits
428 
429  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
430  > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
431 
432  In this class, the array's limit of nesting is not constraint explicitly.
433  However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
434  runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the @ref
435  max_size function of a JSON array.
436 
437  #### Storage
438 
439  Arrays are stored as pointers in a `basic_json` type. That is, for any
440  access to array values, a pointer of type `array_t*` must be dereferenced.
441  */
442  using array_t = ArrayType<basic_json, AllocatorType<basic_json>>;
443 
444  /*!
445  @brief a type for a string
446 
447  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON strings as follows:
448  > A string is a sequence of zero or more Unicode characters.
449 
450  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters @a
451  StringType which chooses the container (e.g., `std::string`) to use.
452 
453  Unicode values are split by the JSON class into byte-sized characters
454  during deserialization.
455 
456  #### Default type
457 
458  With the default values for @a StringType (`std::string`), the default
459  value for @a string_t is:
460 
461  @code {.cpp}
462  std::string
463  @endcode
464 
465  #### String comparison
466 
467  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
468  > Software implementations are typically required to test names of object
469  > members for equality. Implementations that transform the textual
470  > representation into sequences of Unicode code units and then perform the
471  > comparison numerically, code unit by code unit, are interoperable in the
472  > sense that implementations will agree in all cases on equality or
473  > inequality of two strings. For example, implementations that compare
474  > strings with escaped characters unconverted may incorrectly find that
475  > `"a\\b"` and `"a\u005Cb"` are not equal.
476 
477  This implementation is interoperable as it does compare strings code unit
478  by code unit.
479 
480  #### Storage
481 
482  String values are stored as pointers in a `basic_json` type. That is, for
483  any access to string values, a pointer of type `string_t*` must be
484  dereferenced.
485  */
486  using string_t = StringType;
487 
488  /*!
489  @brief a type for a boolean
490 
491  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) implicitly describes a boolean as a
492  type which differentiates the two literals `true` and `false`.
493 
494  To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter @a
495  BooleanType which chooses the type to use.
496 
497  #### Default type
498 
499  With the default values for @a BooleanType (`bool`), the default value for
500  @a boolean_t is:
501 
502  @code {.cpp}
503  bool
504  @endcode
505 
506  #### Storage
507 
508  Boolean values are stored directly inside a `basic_json` type.
509  */
510  using boolean_t = BooleanType;
511 
512  /*!
513  @brief a type for a number (integer)
514 
515  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
516  > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most programming
517  > languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal digits. It
518  > contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an optional minus
519  > sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an exponent part.
520  > Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that cannot be
521  > represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN) are not
522  > permitted.
523 
524  This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers. However,
525  C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number is an
526  integer or a floating-point number. Therefore, two different types, @ref
527  number_integer_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
528 
529  To store integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
530  parameter @a NumberIntegerType which chooses the type to use.
531 
532  #### Default type
533 
534  With the default values for @a NumberIntegerType (`int64_t`), the default
535  value for @a number_integer_t is:
536 
537  @code {.cpp}
538  int64_t
539  @endcode
540 
541  #### Default behavior
542 
543  - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
544  leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
545  number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
546  instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`. During
547  deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
548  - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
549 
550  #### Limits
551 
552  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
553  > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
554 
555  When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
556  stored is `9223372036854775807` (INT64_MAX) and the minimal integer number
557  that can be stored is `-9223372036854775808` (INT64_MIN). Integer numbers
558  that are out of range will yield over/underflow when used in a constructor.
559  During deserialization, too large or small integer numbers will be
560  automatically be stored as @ref number_float_t.
561 
562  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
563  > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
564  > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
565  > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
566 
567  As this range is a subrange of the exactly supported range [INT64_MIN,
568  INT64_MAX], this class's integer type is interoperable.
569 
570  #### Storage
571 
572  Integer number values are stored directly inside a `basic_json` type.
573  */
574  using number_integer_t = NumberIntegerType;
575 
576  /*!
577  @brief a type for a number (floating-point)
578 
579  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
580  > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most programming
581  > languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal digits. It
582  > contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an optional minus
583  > sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an exponent part.
584  > Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that cannot be
585  > represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN) are not
586  > permitted.
587 
588  This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers. However,
589  C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number is an
590  integer or a floating-point number. Therefore, two different types, @ref
591  number_integer_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
592 
593  To store floating-point numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
594  parameter @a NumberFloatType which chooses the type to use.
595 
596  #### Default type
597 
598  With the default values for @a NumberFloatType (`double`), the default
599  value for @a number_float_t is:
600 
601  @code {.cpp}
602  double
603  @endcode
604 
605  #### Default behavior
606 
607  - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
608  leading zeros in floating-point literals will be ignored. Internally, the
609  value will be stored as decimal number. For instance, the C++
610  floating-point literal `01.2` will be serialized to `1.2`. During
611  deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
612  - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
613 
614  #### Limits
615 
616  [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
617  > This specification allows implementations to set limits on the range and
618  > precision of numbers accepted. Since software that implements IEEE
619  > 754-2008 binary64 (double precision) numbers is generally available and
620  > widely used, good interoperability can be achieved by implementations that
621  > expect no more precision or range than these provide, in the sense that
622  > implementations will approximate JSON numbers within the expected
623  > precision.
624 
625  This implementation does exactly follow this approach, as it uses double
626  precision floating-point numbers. Note values smaller than
627  `-1.79769313486232e+308` and values greather than `1.79769313486232e+308`
628  will be stored as NaN internally and be serialized to `null`.
629 
630  #### Storage
631 
632  Floating-point number values are stored directly inside a `basic_json` type.
633  */
634  using number_float_t = NumberFloatType;
635 
636  /// @}
637 
638 
639  ///////////////////////////
640  // JSON type enumeration //
641  ///////////////////////////
642 
643  /*!
644  @brief the JSON type enumeration
645 
646  This enumeration collects the different JSON types. It is internally used
647  to distinguish the stored values, and the functions is_null, is_object,
648  is_array, is_string, is_boolean, is_number, and is_discarded rely on it.
649  */
650  enum class value_t : uint8_t
651  {
652  null, ///< null value
653  object, ///< object (unordered set of name/value pairs)
654  array, ///< array (ordered collection of values)
655  string, ///< string value
656  boolean, ///< boolean value
657  number_integer, ///< number value (integer)
658  number_float, ///< number value (floating-point)
659  discarded ///< discarded by the the parser callback function
660  };
661 
662 
663  private:
664  /// helper for exception-safe object creation
665  template<typename T, typename... Args>
666  static T* create(Args&& ... args)
667  {
668  AllocatorType<T> alloc;
669  auto deleter = [&](T * object)
670  {
671  alloc.deallocate(object, 1);
672  };
673  std::unique_ptr<T, decltype(deleter)> object(alloc.allocate(1), deleter);
674  alloc.construct(object.get(), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
675  return object.release();
676  }
677 
678  ////////////////////////
679  // JSON value storage //
680  ////////////////////////
681 
682  /// a JSON value
683  union json_value
684  {
685  /// object (stored with pointer to save storage)
686  object_t* object;
687  /// array (stored with pointer to save storage)
688  array_t* array;
689  /// string (stored with pointer to save storage)
690  string_t* string;
691  /// boolean
692  boolean_t boolean;
693  /// number (integer)
694  number_integer_t number_integer;
695  /// number (floating-point)
696  number_float_t number_float;
697 
698  /// default constructor (for null values)
699  json_value() noexcept = default;
700  /// constructor for booleans
701  json_value(boolean_t v) noexcept : boolean(v) {}
702  /// constructor for numbers (integer)
703  json_value(number_integer_t v) noexcept : number_integer(v) {}
704  /// constructor for numbers (floating-point)
705  json_value(number_float_t v) noexcept : number_float(v) {}
706  /// constructor for empty values of a given type
707  json_value(value_t t)
708  {
709  switch (t)
710  {
711  case (value_t::null):
712  case (value_t::discarded):
713  {
714  break;
715  }
716 
717  case (value_t::object):
718  {
719  object = create<object_t>();
720  break;
721  }
722 
723  case (value_t::array):
724  {
725  array = create<array_t>();
726  break;
727  }
728 
729  case (value_t::string):
730  {
731  string = create<string_t>("");
732  break;
733  }
734 
735  case (value_t::boolean):
736  {
737  boolean = boolean_t(false);
738  break;
739  }
740 
741  case (value_t::number_integer):
742  {
743  number_integer = number_integer_t(0);
744  break;
745  }
746 
747  case (value_t::number_float):
748  {
749  number_float = number_float_t(0.0);
750  break;
751  }
752  }
753  }
754 
755  /// constructor for strings
756  json_value(const string_t& value)
757  {
758  string = create<string_t>(value);
759  }
760 
761  /// constructor for objects
762  json_value(const object_t& value)
763  {
764  object = create<object_t>(value);
765  }
766 
767  /// constructor for arrays
768  json_value(const array_t& value)
769  {
770  array = create<array_t>(value);
771  }
772  };
773 
774 
775  public:
776  //////////////////////////
777  // JSON parser callback //
778  //////////////////////////
779 
780  /*!
781  @brief JSON callback events
782 
783  This enumeration lists the parser events that can trigger calling a
784  callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t during parsing.
785  */
786  enum class parse_event_t : uint8_t
787  {
788  /// the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
789  object_start,
790  /// the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
791  object_end,
792  /// the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
793  array_start,
794  /// the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
795  array_end,
796  /// the parser read a key of a value in an object
797  key,
798  /// the parser finished reading a JSON value
799  value
800  };
801 
802  /*!
803  @brief per-element parser callback type
804 
805  With a parser callback function, the result of parsing a JSON text can be
806  influenced. When passed to @ref parse(std::istream&, parser_callback_t) or
807  @ref parse(const string_t&, parser_callback_t), it is called on certain
808  events (passed as @ref parse_event_t via parameter @a event) with a set
809  recursion depth @a depth and context JSON value @a parsed. The return value
810  of the callback function is a boolean indicating whether the element that
811  emitted the callback shall be kept or not.
812 
813  We distinguish six scenarios (determined by the event type) in which the
814  callback function can be called. The following table describes the values
815  of the parameters @a depth, @a event, and @a parsed.
816 
817  parameter @a event | description | parameter @a depth | parameter @a parsed
818  ------------------ | ----------- | ------------------ | -------------------
819  parse_event_t::object_start | the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | a JSON value with type discarded
820  parse_event_t::key | the parser read a key of a value in an object | depth of the currently parsed JSON object | a JSON string containing the key
821  parse_event_t::object_end | the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | the parsed JSON object
822  parse_event_t::array_start | the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | a JSON value with type discarded
823  parse_event_t::array_end | the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | the parsed JSON array
824  parse_event_t::value | the parser finished reading a JSON value | depth of the value | the parsed JSON value
825 
826  Discarding a value (i.e., returning `false`) has different effects depending on the
827  context in which function was called:
828 
829  - Discarded values in structured types are skipped. That is, the parser
830  will behave as if the discarded value was never read.
831  - In case a value outside a structured type is skipped, it is replaced with
832  `null`. This case happens if the top-level element is skipped.
833 
834  @param[in] depth the depth of the recursion during parsing
835 
836  @param[in] event an event of type parse_event_t indicating the context in
837  the callback function has been called
838 
839  @param[in,out] parsed the current intermediate parse result; note that
840  writing to this value has no effect for parse_event_t::key events
841 
842  @return Whether the JSON value which called the function during parsing
843  should be kept (`true`) or not (`false`). In the latter case, it is either
844  skipped completely or replaced by an empty discarded object.
845 
846  @sa @ref parse(std::istream&, parser_callback_t) or
847  @ref parse(const string_t&, parser_callback_t) for examples
848  */
849  using parser_callback_t = std::function<bool(
850  int depth, parse_event_t event, basic_json& parsed)>;
851 
852 
853  //////////////////
854  // constructors //
855  //////////////////
856 
857  /*!
858  @brief create an empty value with a given type
859 
860  Create an empty JSON value with a given type. The value will be default
861  initialized with an empty value which depends on the type:
862 
863  Value type | initial value
864  ----------- | -------------
865  null | `null`
866  boolean | `false`
867  string | `""`
868  number | `0`
869  object | `{}`
870  array | `[]`
871 
872  @param[in] value the type of the value to create
873 
874  @complexity Constant.
875 
876  @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string value
877  fails
878 
879  @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor for different @ref
880  value_t values,basic_json__value_t}
881  */

883  : m_type(value), m_value(value)
884  {}

1131  the interface.

1136  basic_json(const int value), so we need to switch this one off in case

1138

1212  @brief create a floating-point number (explicit)
1213 
1214  Create a floating-point number JSON value with a given content.
1215 
1216  @param[in] value a floating-point value to create a JSON number from
1217 
1218  @note RFC 7159 <http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7159.txt>, section 6
1219  disallows NaN values:
1220  > Numeric values that cannot be represented in the grammar below (such
1221  > as Infinity and NaN) are not permitted.
1222  In case the parameter @a value is not a number, a JSON null value is
1223  created instead.
1224

1226 
1227  @liveexample{The following example creates several floating-point
1228  values.,basic_json__number_float_t}
1229  */
1230  basic_json(const number_float_t value)
1231  : m_type(value_t::number_float), m_value(value)
1232  {
1233  // replace infinity and NAN by null
1234  if (not std::isfinite(value))
1235  {
1236  m_type = value_t::null;
1237  m_value = json_value();
1238  }
1239  }

1242  @brief create an floating-point number (implicit)
1243 
1244  Create an floating-point number JSON value with a given content. This
1245  constructor allows any type that can be used to construct values of type
1246  @ref number_float_t. Examples may include the types `float`.
1247 
1248  @tparam CompatibleNumberFloatType a floating-point type which is compatible
1249  to @ref number_float_t.
1250 
1251  @param[in] value a floating-point to create a JSON number from
1252 
1253  @note RFC 7159 <http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7159.txt>, section 6
1254  disallows NaN values:
1255  > Numeric values that cannot be represented in the grammar below (such
1256  > as Infinity and NaN) are not permitted.
1257  In case the parameter @a value is not a number, a JSON null value is
1258  created instead.
1259 
1260  @complexity Constant.
1261 
1262  @liveexample{The example below shows the construction of several JSON
1263  floating-point number values from compatible
1264  types.,basic_json__CompatibleNumberFloatType}
1265 
1266  @sa basic_json(const number_float_t)
1267  */
1268  template<typename CompatibleNumberFloatType, typename = typename
1269  std::enable_if<
1270  std::is_constructible<number_float_t, CompatibleNumberFloatType>::value and
1271  std::is_floating_point<CompatibleNumberFloatType>::value>::type
1272  >
1273  basic_json(const CompatibleNumberFloatType value) noexcept
1274  : basic_json(number_float_t(value))
1275  {}

1277  /*!
1278  @brief create json where a user defined conversion exists.
1279  */
1280  template<typename T, typename = typename std::enable_if<JsonTraits<T>::hasUser>::type>
1281  basic_json(const T& t) : basic_json(JsonConvert<T>::toJson(t))
1282  {}
1283 
1284  /*!
1285  @brief create a container (array or object) from an initializer list
1286 
1287  Creates a JSON value of type array or object from the passed initializer
1288  list @a init. In case @a type_deduction is `true` (default), the type of
1289  the JSON value to be created is deducted from the initializer list @a init
1290  according to the following rules:
1291 
1292  1. If the list is empty, an empty JSON object value `{}` is created.
1293  2. If the list consists of pairs whose first element is a string, a JSON
1294  object value is created where the first elements of the pairs are treated
1295  as keys and the second elements are as values.
1296  3. In all other cases, an array is created.
1297 
1298  The rules aim to create the best fit between a C++ initializer list and
1299  JSON values. The ratioinale is as follows:
1300 
1301  1. The empty initializer list is written as `{}` which is exactly an empty
1302  JSON object.
1303  2. C++ has now way of describing mapped types other than to list a list of
1304  pairs. As JSON requires that keys must be of type string, rule 2 is the
1305  weakest constraint one can pose on initializer lists to interpret them as
1306  an object.
1307  3. In all other cases, the initializer list could not be interpreted as
1308  JSON object type, so interpreting it as JSON array type is safe.
1309 
1310  With the rules described above, the following JSON values cannot be
1311  expressed by an initializer list:
1312 
1313  - the empty array (`[]`): use @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>)
1314  with an empty initializer list in this case
1315  - arrays whose elements satisfy rule 2: use @ref
1316  array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) with the same initializer list
1317  in this case
1318 
1319  @note When used without parentheses around an empty initializer list, @ref
1320  basic_json() is called instead of this function, yielding the JSON null
1321  value.
1322 
1323  @param[in] init initializer list with JSON values
1324 
1325  @param[in] type_deduction internal parameter; when set to `true`, the type
1326  of the JSON value is deducted from the initializer list @a init; when set
1327  to `false`, the type provided via @a manual_type is forced. This mode is
1328  used by the functions @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) and
1329  @ref object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>).
1330 
1331  @param[in] manual_type internal parameter; when @a type_deduction is set to
1332  `false`, the created JSON value will use the provided type (only @ref
1333  value_t::array and @ref value_t::object are valid); when @a type_deduction
1334  is set to `true`, this parameter has no effect
1335 
1336  @throw std::domain_error if @a type_deduction is `false`, @a manual_type is
1337  `value_t::object`, but @a init contains an element which is not a pair
1338  whose first element is a string
1339 
1340  @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
1341 
1342  @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values are created from
1343  initializer lists,basic_json__list_init_t}
1344 
1345  @sa basic_json array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) - create a JSON
1346  array value from an initializer list
1347  @sa basic_json object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) - create a JSON
1348  object value from an initializer list
1349  */
1350  basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init,
1351  bool type_deduction = true,
1352  value_t manual_type = value_t::array)
1353  {
1354  // the initializer list could describe an object
1355  bool is_object = true;
1356 
1357  // check if each element is an array with two elements whose first element
1358  // is a string
1359  for (const auto& element : init)
1360  {
1361  if (element.m_type != value_t::array or element.size() != 2
1362  or element[0].m_type != value_t::string)
1363  {
1364  // we found an element that makes it impossible to use the
1365  // initializer list as object
1366  is_object = false;
1367  break;
1368  }
1369  }
1370 
1371  // adjust type if type deduction is not wanted
1372  if (not type_deduction)
1373  {
1374  // if array is wanted, do not create an object though possible
1375  if (manual_type == value_t::array)
1376  {
1377  is_object = false;
1378  }
1379 
1380  // if object is wanted but impossible, throw an exception
1381  if (manual_type == value_t::object and not is_object)
1382  {
1383  throw std::domain_error("cannot create object from initializer list");
1384  }
1385  }
1386 
1387  if (is_object)
1388  {
1389  // the initializer list is a list of pairs -> create object
1390  m_type = value_t::object;
1391  m_value = value_t::object;
1392 
1393  for (auto& element : init)
1394  {
1395  m_value.object->emplace(std::move(*(element[0].m_value.string)), std::move(element[1]));
1396  }
1397  }
1398  else
1399  {
1400  // the initializer list describes an array -> create array
1401  m_type = value_t::array;
1402  m_value.array = create<array_t>(std::move(init));
1403  }
1404  }
1405 
1406  /*!
1407  @brief explicitly create an array from an initializer list
1408 
1409  Creates a JSON array value from a given initializer list. That is, given a
1410  list of values `a, b, c`, creates the JSON value `[a, b, c]`. If the
1411  initializer list is empty, the empty array `[]` is created.
1412 
1413  @note This function is only needed to express two edge cases that cannot be
1414  realized with the initializer list constructor (@ref
1415  basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t)). These cases
1416  are:
1417  1. creating an array whose elements are all pairs whose first element is a
1418  string - in this case, the initializer list constructor would create an
1419  object, taking the first elements as keys
1420  2. creating an empty array - passing the empty initializer list to the
1421  initializer list constructor yields an empty object
1422 
1423  @param[in] init initializer list with JSON values to create an array from
1424  (optional)
1425 
1426  @return JSON array value
1427 
1428  @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
1429 
1430  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the @ref array
1431  function.,array}
1432 
1433  @sa basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t) - create a
1434  JSON value from an initializer list
1435  @sa basic_json object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) - create a JSON
1436  object value from an initializer list
1437  */
1438  static basic_json array(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init =
1439  std::initializer_list<basic_json>())
1440  {
1441  return basic_json(init, false, value_t::array);
1442  }
1443 
1444  /*!
1445  @brief explicitly create an object from an initializer list
1446 
1447  Creates a JSON object value from a given initializer list. The initializer
1448  lists elements must be pairs, and their first elments must be strings. If
1449  the initializer list is empty, the empty object `{}` is created.
1450 
1451  @note This function is only added for symmetry reasons. In contrast to the
1452  related function @ref basic_json array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>),
1453  there are no cases which can only be expressed by this function. That is,
1454  any initializer list @a init can also be passed to the initializer list
1455  constructor @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool,
1456  value_t).
1457 
1458  @param[in] init initializer list to create an object from (optional)
1459 
1460  @return JSON object value
1461 
1462  @throw std::domain_error if @a init is not a pair whose first elements are
1463  strings; thrown by @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool,
1464  value_t)
1465 
1466  @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
1467 
1468  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the @ref object
1469  function.,object}
1470 
1471  @sa basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t) - create a
1472  JSON value from an initializer list
1473  @sa basic_json array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) - create a JSON
1474  array value from an initializer list
1475  */
1476  static basic_json object(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init =
1477  std::initializer_list<basic_json>())
1478  {
1479  return basic_json(init, false, value_t::object);
1480  }
1481 
1482  /*!
1483  @brief construct an array with count copies of given value
1484 
1485  Constructs a JSON array value by creating @a count copies of a passed
1486  value. In case @a count is `0`, an empty array is created. As postcondition,
1487  `std::distance(begin(),end()) == count` holds.
1488 
1489  @param[in] count the number of JSON copies of @a value to create
1490  @param[in] value the JSON value to copy
1491 
1492  @complexity Linear in @a count.
1493 
1494  @liveexample{The following code shows examples for the @ref
1495  basic_json(size_type\, const basic_json&)
1496  constructor.,basic_json__size_type_basic_json}
1497  */
1498  basic_json(size_type count, const basic_json& value)
1499  : m_type(value_t::array)
1500  {
1501  m_value.array = create<array_t>(count, value);
1502  }
1503 
1504  /*!
1505  @brief construct a JSON container given an iterator range
1506 
1507  Constructs the JSON value with the contents of the range `[first, last)`.
1508  The semantics depends on the different types a JSON value can have:
1509  - In case of primitive types (number, boolean, or string), @a first must
1510  be `begin()` and @a last must be `end()`. In this case, the value is
1511  copied. Otherwise, std::out_of_range is thrown.
1512  - In case of structured types (array, object), the constructor behaves
1513  as similar versions for `std::vector`.
1514  - In case of a null type, std::domain_error is thrown.
1515 
1516  @tparam InputIT an input iterator type (@ref iterator or @ref
1517  const_iterator)
1518 
1519  @param[in] first begin of the range to copy from (included)
1520  @param[in] last end of the range to copy from (excluded)
1521 
1522  @throw std::domain_error if iterators are not compatible; that is, do not
1523  belong to the same JSON value
1524  @throw std::out_of_range if iterators are for a primitive type (number,
1525  boolean, or string) where an out of range error can be detected easily
1526  @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string fails
1527  @throw std::domain_error if called with a null value
1528 
1529  @complexity Linear in distance between @a first and @a last.
1530 
1531  @liveexample{The example below shows several ways to create JSON values by
1532  specifying a subrange with iterators.,basic_json__InputIt_InputIt}
1533  */
1534  template <class InputIT, typename
1535  std::enable_if<
1536  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
1537  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value
1538  , int>::type
1539  = 0>
1540  basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last) : m_type(first.m_object->m_type)
1541  {
1542  // make sure iterator fits the current value
1543  if (first.m_object != last.m_object)
1544  {
1545  throw std::domain_error("iterators are not compatible");
1546  }
1547 
1548  // check if iterator range is complete for primitive values
1549  switch (m_type)
1550  {
1551  case value_t::number_integer:
1552  case value_t::number_float:
1553  case value_t::boolean:
1554  case value_t::string:
1555  {
1556  if (not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end())
1557  {
1558  throw std::out_of_range("iterators out of range");
1559  }
1560  break;
1561  }
1562 
1563  default:
1564  {
1565  break;
1566  }
1567  }
1568 
1569  switch (m_type)
1570  {
1571  case value_t::number_integer:
1572  {
1573  m_value.number_integer = first.m_object->m_value.number_integer;
1574  break;
1575  }
1576 
1577  case value_t::number_float:
1578  {
1579  m_value.number_float = first.m_object->m_value.number_float;
1580  break;
1581  }
1582 
1583  case value_t::boolean:
1584  {
1585  m_value.boolean = first.m_object->m_value.boolean;
1586  break;
1587  }
1588 
1589  case value_t::string:
1590  {
1591  m_value = *first.m_object->m_value.string;
1592  break;
1593  }
1594 
1595  case value_t::object:
1596  {
1597  m_value.object = create<object_t>(first.m_it.object_iterator, last.m_it.object_iterator);
1598  break;
1599  }
1600 
1601  case value_t::array:
1602  {
1603  m_value.array = create<array_t>(first.m_it.array_iterator, last.m_it.array_iterator);
1604  break;
1605  }
1606 
1607  default:
1608  {
1609  throw std::domain_error("cannot use construct with iterators from " + first.m_object->type_name());
1610  }
1611  }
1612  }
1613 
1614  ///////////////////////////////////////
1615  // other constructors and destructor //
1616  ///////////////////////////////////////
1617 
1618  /*!
1619  @brief copy constructor
1620 
1621  Creates a copy of a given JSON value.
1622 
1623  @param[in] other the JSON value to copy
1624 
1625  @complexity Linear in the size of @a other.
1626 
1627  @requirement This function satisfies the Container requirements:
1628  - The complexity is linear.
1629  - As postcondition, it holds: `other == basic_json(other)`.
1630 
1631  @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string fails.
1632 
1633  @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the copy
1634  constructor.,basic_json__basic_json}
1635  */
1636  basic_json(const basic_json& other)
1637  : m_type(other.m_type)
1638  {
1639  switch (m_type)
1640  {
1641  case (value_t::null):
1642  case (value_t::discarded):
1643  {
1644  break;
1645  }
1646 
1647  case (value_t::object):
1648  {
1649  m_value = *other.m_value.object;
1650  break;
1651  }
1652 
1653  case (value_t::array):
1654  {
1655  m_value = *other.m_value.array;
1656  break;
1657  }
1658 
1659  case (value_t::string):
1660  {
1661  m_value = *other.m_value.string;
1662  break;
1663  }
1664 
1665  case (value_t::boolean):
1666  {
1667  m_value = other.m_value.boolean;
1668  break;
1669  }
1670 
1671  case (value_t::number_integer):
1672  {
1673  m_value = other.m_value.number_integer;
1674  break;
1675  }
1676 
1677  case (value_t::number_float):
1678  {
1679  m_value = other.m_value.number_float;
1680  break;
1681  }
1682  }
1683  }
1684 
1685  /*!
1686  @brief move constructor
1687 
1688  Move constructor. Constructs a JSON value with the contents of the given
1689  value @a other using move semantics. It "steals" the resources from @a
1690  other and leaves it as JSON null value.
1691 
1692  @param[in,out] other value to move to this object
1693 
1694  @post @a other is a JSON null value
1695 
1696  @complexity Constant.
1697 
1698  @liveexample{The code below shows the move constructor explicitly called
1699  via std::move.,basic_json__moveconstructor}
1700  */
1701  basic_json(basic_json&& other) noexcept
1702  : m_type(std::move(other.m_type)),
1703  m_value(std::move(other.m_value))
1704  {
1705  // invalidate payload
1706  other.m_type = value_t::null;
1707  other.m_value = {};
1708  }
1709 
1710  /*!
1711  @brief copy assignment
1712 
1713  Copy assignment operator. Copies a JSON value via the "copy and swap"
1714  strategy: It is expressed in terms of the copy constructor, destructor, and
1715  the swap() member function.
1716 
1717  @param[in] other value to copy from
1718 
1719  @complexity Linear.
1720 
1721  @requirement This function satisfies the Container requirements:
1722  - The complexity is linear.
1723 
1724  @liveexample{The code below shows and example for the copy assignment. It
1725  creates a copy of value `a` which is then swapped with `b`. Finally\, the
1726  copy of `a` (which is the null value after the swap) is
1727  destroyed.,basic_json__copyassignment}
1728  */
1729  reference& operator=(basic_json other) noexcept (
1730  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
1731  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
1732  std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
1733  std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value
1734  )
1735  {
1736  using std::swap;
1737  swap(m_type, other.m_type);
1738  swap(m_value, other.m_value);
1739  return *this;
1740  }
1741 
1742  /*!
1743  @brief destructor
1744 
1745  Destroys the JSON value and frees all allocated memory.
1746 
1747  @complexity Linear.
1748 
1749  @requirement This function satisfies the Container requirements:
1750  - The complexity is linear.
1751  - All stored elements are destroyed and all memory is freed.
1752  */
1753  ~basic_json()
1754  {
1755  switch (m_type)
1756  {
1757  case (value_t::object):
1758  {
1759  AllocatorType<object_t> alloc;
1760  alloc.destroy(m_value.object);
1761  alloc.deallocate(m_value.object, 1);
1762  break;
1763  }
1764 
1765  case (value_t::array):
1766  {
1767  AllocatorType<array_t> alloc;
1768  alloc.destroy(m_value.array);
1769  alloc.deallocate(m_value.array, 1);
1770  break;
1771  }
1772 
1773  case (value_t::string):
1774  {
1775  AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
1776  alloc.destroy(m_value.string);
1777  alloc.deallocate(m_value.string, 1);
1778  break;
1779  }
1780 
1781  default:
1782  {
1783  // all other types need no specific destructor
1784  break;
1785  }
1786  }
1787  }

1791  ///////////////////////

1796  /// @{

1798  /*!
1799  @brief serialization
1800 
1801  Serialization function for JSON values. The function tries to mimick
1802  Python's @p json.dumps() function, and currently supports its @p indent
1803  parameter.
1804 
1805  @param[in] indent if indent is nonnegative, then array elements and object
1806  members will be pretty-printed with that indent level. An indent level of 0
1807  will only insert newlines. -1 (the default) selects the most compact
1808  representation
1809 
1810  @return string containing the serialization of the JSON value
1811 
1812  @complexity Linear.
1813 
1814  @liveexample{The following example shows the effect of different @a indent
1815  parameters to the result of the serializaion.,dump}
1816 
1817  @see https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump
1818  */
1819  string_t dump(const int indent = -1) const
1820  {
1821  std::stringstream ss;
1822 
1823  if (indent >= 0)
1824  {
1825  dump(ss, true, static_cast<unsigned int>(indent));
1826  }
1827  else
1828  {
1829  dump(ss, false, 0);
1830  }
1831 
1832  return ss.str();
1833  }

2064  operator value_t() const noexcept
2065  {
2066  return m_type;

2076  /// get an object (explicit)
2077  template <class T, typename
2078  std::enable_if<
2079  std::is_convertible<typename object_t::key_type, typename T::key_type>::value and
2080  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, typename T::mapped_type>::value
2081  , int>::type = 0>
2082  T get_impl(T*) const
2083  {
2084  switch (m_type)
2085  {
2086  case (value_t::object):
2087  {
2088  return T(m_value.object->begin(), m_value.object->end());
2089  }
2090  default:
2091  {
2092  throw std::domain_error("type must be object, but is " + type_name());
2093  }
2094  }
2095  }

2114  template <class T, typename
2115  std::enable_if<
2116  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, typename T::value_type>::value and
2117  not std::is_same<basic_json_t, typename T::value_type>::value and
2118  not std::is_arithmetic<T>::value and
2119  not std::is_convertible<std::string, T>::value and
2120  not has_mapped_type<T>::value
2121  , int>::type = 0>

2123  {

2128  T to_vector;

2130  std::inserter(to_vector, to_vector.end()), [](basic_json i)
2131  {

2133  });
2134  return to_vector;

2139  }
2140  }

2342  /// @name value access
2343  /// @{
2344 
2345  /*!
2346  @brief get a value (explicit)
2347 
2348  Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
2349 
2350  @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
2351  instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
2352  `std::vector` types for JSON arrays
2353 
2354  @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
2355 
2356  @throw std::domain_error in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
2357  to JSON
2358 
2359  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
2360 
2361  @liveexample{The example below shows serveral conversions from JSON values
2362  to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
2363  be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
2364  `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
2365  assiciative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
2366  json>`.,get__ValueType_const}
2367 
2368  @internal
2369  The idea of using a casted null pointer to choose the correct
2370  implementation is from <http://stackoverflow.com/a/8315197/266378>.
2371  @endinternal
2372 
2373  @sa @ref operator ValueType() const for implicit conversion
2374  @sa @ref get() for pointer-member access
2375  */
2376  template<typename ValueType, typename
2377  std::enable_if<
2378  not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value
2379  , int>::type = 0>
2380  ValueType get() const
2381  {
2382  return get_impl(static_cast<ValueType*>(nullptr));
2383  }
2384 
2385  /*!
2386  @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
2387 
2388  Explicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
2389  made.
2390 
2391  @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
2392  state.
2393 
2394  @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
2395  object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or @ref
2396  number_float_t.
2397 
2398  @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested pointer
2399  type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
2400 
2401  @complexity Constant.
2402 
2403  @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
2404  JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
2405  `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
2406  match.,get__PointerType}
2407 
2408  @sa @ref get_ptr() for explicit pointer-member access
2409  */
2410  template<typename PointerType, typename
2411  std::enable_if<
2412  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value
2413  , int>::type = 0>
2414  PointerType get() noexcept
2415  {
2416  // delegate the call to get_ptr
2417  return get_ptr<PointerType>();
2418  }
2419 
2420  /*!
2421  @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
2422  @copydoc get()
2423  */
2424  template<typename PointerType, typename
2425  std::enable_if<
2426  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value
2427  , int>::type = 0>
2428  const PointerType get() const noexcept
2429  {
2430  // delegate the call to get_ptr
2431  return get_ptr<PointerType>();
2432  }
2433 
2434  /*!
2435  @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
2436 
2437  Implict pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
2438  made.
2439 
2440  @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
2441  state.
2442 
2443  @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
2444  object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or @ref
2445  number_float_t.
2446 
2447  @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested pointer
2448  type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
2449 
2450  @complexity Constant.
2451 
2452  @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
2453  JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
2454  `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
2455  match.,get_ptr}
2456  */
2457  template<typename PointerType, typename
2458  std::enable_if<
2459  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value
2460  , int>::type = 0>
2461  PointerType get_ptr() noexcept
2462  {
2463  // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>()
2464  return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
2465  }
2466 
2467  /*!
2468  @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
2469  @copydoc get_ptr()
2470  */
2471  template<typename PointerType, typename
2472  std::enable_if<
2473  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value
2474  and std::is_const<typename std::remove_pointer<PointerType>::type>::value
2475  , int>::type = 0>
2476  const PointerType get_ptr() const noexcept
2477  {
2478  // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>() const
2479  return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<const PointerType>(nullptr));
2480  }
2481 
2482  /*!
2483  @brief get a value (implicit)
2484 
2485  Implict type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value. The
2486  call is realized by calling @ref get() const.
2487 
2488  @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
2489  instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
2490  `std::vector` types for JSON arrays
2491 
2492  @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
2493 
2494  @throw std::domain_error in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
2495  to JSON, thrown by @ref get() const
2496 
2497  @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
2498 
2499  @liveexample{The example below shows serveral conversions from JSON values
2500  to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
2501  be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
2502  `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
2503  assiciative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
2504  json>`.,operator__ValueType}
2505  */
2506  template<typename ValueType, typename
2507  std::enable_if<
2508  not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value
2509  , int>::type = 0>
2510  operator ValueType() const
2511  {
2512  // delegate the call to get<>() const
2513  return get<ValueType>();

2526  /*!
2527  @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
2528 
2529  Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx, with
2530  bounds checking.
2531 
2532  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
2533 
2534  @return reference to the element at index @a idx
2535 
2536  @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an array
2537  @throw std::out_of_range if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
2538  that is, `idx >= size()`
2539 
2540  @complexity Constant.
2541 
2542  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
2543  written using at.,at__size_type}
2544  */

2546  {
2547  // at only works for arrays
2548  if (m_type != value_t::array)
2549  {
2550  throw std::domain_error("cannot use at() with " + type_name());
2551  }
2552 
2553  return m_value.array->at(idx);
2554  }

2646  /*!
2647  @brief access specified array element
2648 
2649  Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
2650 
2651  @note If @a idx is beyond the range of the array (i.e., `idx >= size()`),
2652  then the array is silently filled up with `null` values to make `idx` a
2653  valid reference to the last stored element.
2654 
2655  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
2656 
2657  @return reference to the element at index @a idx
2658 
2659  @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an array or null
2660 
2661  @complexity Constant if @a idx is in the range of the array. Otherwise
2662  linear in `idx - size()`.
2663 
2664  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
2665  written using [] operator. Note the addition of `null`
2666  values.,operatorarray__size_type}
2667  */
2668  reference operator[](size_type idx)
2669  {
2670  // implicitly convert null to object
2671  if (m_type == value_t::null)
2672  {
2673  m_type = value_t::array;
2674  m_value.array = create<array_t>();
2675  }
2676 
2677  // [] only works for arrays
2678  if (m_type != value_t::array)
2679  {
2680  throw std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name());
2681  }
2682 
2683  for (size_t i = m_value.array->size(); i <= idx; ++i)
2684  {
2685  m_value.array->push_back(basic_json());
2686  }
2687 
2688  return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
2689  }
2690 
2691  /*!
2692  @brief access specified array element
2693 
2694  Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
2695 
2696  @param[in] idx index of the element to access
2697 
2698  @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
2699 
2700  @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an array
2701 
2702  @complexity Constant.
2703 
2704  @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
2705  the [] operator.,operatorarray__size_type_const}
2706  */
2707  const_reference operator[](size_type idx) const
2708  {
2709  // at only works for arrays
2710  if (m_type != value_t::array)
2711  {
2712  throw std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name());
2713  }
2714 
2715  return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
2716  }
2717 
2718  /*!
2719  @brief access specified object element
2720 
2721  Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
2722 
2723  @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
2724  the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
2725  In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
2726 
2727  @param[in] key key of the element to access
2728 
2729  @return reference to the element at key @a key
2730 
2731  @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object or null
2732 
2733  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
2734 
2735  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
2736  written using the [] operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
2737  */
2738  reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key)
2739  {
2740  // implicitly convert null to object
2741  if (m_type == value_t::null)
2742  {
2743  m_type = value_t::object;
2744  m_value.object = create<object_t>();
2745  }
2746 
2747  // [] only works for objects
2748  if (m_type != value_t::object)
2749  {
2750  throw std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name());
2751  }
2752 
2753  return m_value.object->operator[](key);
2754  }
2755 
2756  /*!
2757  @brief access specified object element
2758 
2759  Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
2760 
2761  @param[in] key key of the element to access
2762 
2763  @return reference to the element at key @a key
2764 
2765  @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object or null
2766 
2767  @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
2768 
2769  @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
2770  the [] operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
2771  */
2772  const_reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key) const

2921  /*!
2922  @brief remove element given an iterator
2923 
2924  Removes the element specified by iterator @a pos. Invalidates iterators and
2925  references at or after the point of the erase, including the end()
2926  iterator. The iterator @a pos must be valid and dereferenceable. Thus the
2927  end() iterator (which is valid, but is not dereferencable) cannot be used
2928  as a value for @a pos.
2929 
2930  If called on a primitive type other than null, the resulting JSON value
2931  will be `null`.
2932 
2933  @param[in] pos iterator to the element to remove
2934  @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a pos
2935  refers to the last element, the end() iterator is returned.
2936 
2937  @tparam InteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
2938 
2939  @throw std::domain_error if called on a `null` value
2940  @throw std::domain_error if called on an iterator which does not belong to
2941  the current JSON value
2942  @throw std::out_of_range if called on a primitive type with invalid iterator
2943  (i.e., any iterator which is not end())
2944 
2945  @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
2946  - objects: amortized constant
2947  - arrays: linear in distance between pos and the end of the container
2948  - strings: linear in the length of the string
2949  - other types: constant
2950 
2951  @liveexample{The example shows the result of erase for different JSON
2952  types.,erase__IteratorType}
2953  */
2954  template <class InteratorType, typename
2955  std::enable_if<
2956  std::is_same<InteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
2957  std::is_same<InteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value
2958  , int>::type
2959  = 0>
2960  InteratorType erase(InteratorType pos)
2961  {
2962  // make sure iterator fits the current value
2963  if (this != pos.m_object)
2964  {
2965  throw std::domain_error("iterator does not fit current value");
2966  }
2967 
2968  InteratorType result = end();
2969 
2970  switch (m_type)
2971  {
2972  case value_t::number_integer:
2973  case value_t::number_float:
2974  case value_t::boolean:
2975  case value_t::string:
2976  {
2977  if (not pos.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin())
2978  {
2979  throw std::out_of_range("iterator out of range");
2980  }
2981 
2982  if (m_type == value_t::string)
2983  {
2984  delete m_value.string;
2985  m_value.string = nullptr;
2986  }
2987 
2988  m_type = value_t::null;
2989  break;
2990  }
2991 
2992  case value_t::object:
2993  {
2994  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(pos.m_it.object_iterator);
2995  break;
2996  }
2997 
2998  case value_t::array:
2999  {
3000  result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(pos.m_it.array_iterator);
3001  break;
3002  }
3003 
3004  default:
3005  {
3006  throw std::domain_error("cannot use erase() with " + type_name());
3007  }
3008  }
3009 
3010  return result;
3011  }
3012 
3013  /*!
3014  @brief remove elements given an iterator range
3015 
3016  Removes the element specified by the range `[first; last)`. Invalidates
3017  iterators and references at or after the point of the erase, including the
3018  end() iterator. The iterator @a first does not need to be dereferenceable
3019  if `first == last`: erasing an empty range is a no-op.
3020 
3021  If called on a primitive type other than null, the resulting JSON value
3022  will be `null`.
3023 
3024  @param[in] first iterator to the beginning of the range to remove
3025  @param[in] last iterator past the end of the range to remove
3026  @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
3027  second refers to the last element, the end() iterator is returned.
3028 
3029  @tparam InteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
3030 
3031  @throw std::domain_error if called on a `null` value
3032  @throw std::domain_error if called on iterators which does not belong to
3033  the current JSON value
3034  @throw std::out_of_range if called on a primitive type with invalid iterators
3035  (i.e., if `first != begin()` and `last != end()`)
3036 
3037  @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
3038  - objects: `log(size()) + std::distance(first, last)`
3039  - arrays: linear in the distance between @a first and @a last, plus linear
3040  in the distance between @a last and end of the container
3041  - strings: linear in the length of the string
3042  - other types: constant
3043 
3044  @liveexample{The example shows the result of erase for different JSON
3045  types.,erase__IteratorType_IteratorType}
3046  */
3047  template <class InteratorType, typename
3048  std::enable_if<
3049  std::is_same<InteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
3050  std::is_same<InteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value
3051  , int>::type
3052  = 0>
3053  InteratorType erase(InteratorType first, InteratorType last)
3054  {
3055  // make sure iterator fits the current value
3056  if (this != first.m_object or this != last.m_object)
3057  {
3058  throw std::domain_error("iterators do not fit current value");
3059  }
3060 
3061  InteratorType result = end();
3062 
3063  switch (m_type)
3064  {
3065  case value_t::number_integer:
3066  case value_t::number_float:
3067  case value_t::boolean:
3068  case value_t::string:
3069  {
3070  if (not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end())
3071  {
3072  throw std::out_of_range("iterators out of range");
3073  }
3074 
3075  if (m_type == value_t::string)
3076  {
3077  delete m_value.string;
3078  m_value.string = nullptr;
3079  }
3080 
3081  m_type = value_t::null;
3082  break;
3083  }
3084 
3085  case value_t::object:
3086  {
3087  result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(first.m_it.object_iterator,
3088  last.m_it.object_iterator);
3089  break;
3090  }
3091 
3092  case value_t::array:
3093  {
3094  result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(first.m_it.array_iterator,
3095  last.m_it.array_iterator);
3096  break;
3097  }
3098 
3099  default:
3100  {
3101  throw std::domain_error("cannot use erase with " + type_name());
3102  }
3103  }
3104 
3105  return result;
3106  }

3526  number | @c 1
3527  object | result of function object_t::size()
3528  array | result of function array_t::size()
3529 
3530  @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy the
3531  Container concept; that is, their size() functions have
3532  constant complexity.
3533 
3534  @requirement This function satisfies the Container requirements:
3535  - The complexity is constant.
3536  - Has the semantics of `std::distance(begin(), end())`.
3537 
3538  @liveexample{The following code calls @ref size on the different value
3539  types.,size}
3540  */
3541  size_type size() const noexcept
3542  {
3543  switch (m_type)
3544  {
3545  case (value_t::null):
3546  {
3547  return 0;
3548  }
3549 
3550  case (value_t::array):
3551  {
3552  return m_value.array->size();
3553  }
3554 
3555  case (value_t::object):
3556  {
3557  return m_value.object->size();
3558  }
3559 
3560  default:
3561  {
3562  // all other types have size 1
3563  return 1;
3564  }
3565  }
3566  }

3568  /*!
3569  @brief returns the maximum possible number of elements
3570 
3571  Returns the maximum number of elements a JSON value is able to hold due to
3572  system or library implementation limitations, i.e. `std::distance(begin(),
3573  end())` for the JSON value.
3574 
3575  @return The return value depends on the different types and is
3576  defined as follows:
3577  Value type | return value
3578  ----------- | -------------
3579  null | @c 0 (same as size())
3580  boolean | @c 1 (same as size())
3581  string | @c 1 (same as size())
3582  number | @c 1 (same as size())
3583  object | result of function object_t::max_size()
3584  array | result of function array_t::max_size()
3585 
3586  @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy the
3587  Container concept; that is, their max_size() functions have
3588  constant complexity.
3589 
3590  @requirement This function satisfies the Container requirements:
3591  - The complexity is constant.
3592  - Has the semantics of returning `b.size()` where `b` is the largest
3593  possible JSON value.
3594 
3595  @liveexample{The following code calls @ref max_size on the different value
3596  types. Note the output is implementation specific.,max_size}
3597  */

3599  {
3600  switch (m_type)
3601  {
3602  case (value_t::array):
3603  {
3604  return m_value.array->max_size();
3605  }
3606 
3607  case (value_t::object):
3608  {
3609  return m_value.object->max_size();
3610  }
3611 
3612  default:
3613  {
3614  // all other types have max_size() == size()
3615  return size();
3616  }
3617  }
3618  }

4126  //////////////////////////////////////////
4127  // lexicographical comparison operators //

4130  /// @name lexicographical comparison operators
4131  /// @{
4132 
4133  private:
4134  /*!
4135  @brief comparison operator for JSON types
4136 
4137  Returns an ordering that is similar to Python:
4138  - order: null < boolean < number < object < array < string
4139  - furthermore, each type is not smaller than itself
4140  */
4141  friend bool operator<(const value_t lhs, const value_t rhs)
4142  {
4143  static constexpr std::array<uint8_t, 7> order = {{
4144  0, // null
4145  3, // object
4146  4, // array
4147  5, // string
4148  1, // boolean
4149  2, // integer
4150  2 // float
4151  }
4152  };
4153 
4154  // discarded values are not comparable
4155  if (lhs == value_t::discarded or rhs == value_t::discarded)
4156  {
4157  return false;
4158  }
4159 
4160  return order[static_cast<std::size_t>(lhs)] < order[static_cast<std::size_t>(rhs)];
4161  }
4162 
4163  public:
4164  /*!
4165  @brief comparison: equal
4166 
4167  Compares two JSON values for equality according to the following rules:
4168  - Two JSON values are equal if (1) they are from the same type and (2)
4169  their stored values are the same.
4170  - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
4171  comparison. Floating-point numbers are compared indirectly: two
4172  floating-point numbers `f1` and `f2` are considered equal if neither
4173  `f1 > f2` nor `f2 > f1` holds.
4174  - Two JSON null values are equal.
4175 
4176  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
4177  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
4178  @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are equal
4179 
4180  @complexity Linear.
4181 
4182  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
4183  types.,operator__equal}
4184  */
4185  friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
4186  {
4187  const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
4188  const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
4189 
4190  if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
4191  {
4192  switch (lhs_type)
4193  {
4194  case (value_t::array):
4195  return *lhs.m_value.array == *rhs.m_value.array;
4196  case (value_t::object):
4197  return *lhs.m_value.object == *rhs.m_value.object;
4198  case (value_t::null):
4199  return true;
4200  case (value_t::string):
4201  return *lhs.m_value.string == *rhs.m_value.string;
4202  case (value_t::boolean):
4203  return lhs.m_value.boolean == rhs.m_value.boolean;
4204  case (value_t::number_integer):
4205  return lhs.m_value.number_integer == rhs.m_value.number_integer;
4206  case (value_t::number_float):
4207  return approx(lhs.m_value.number_float, rhs.m_value.number_float);
4208  case (value_t::discarded):
4209  return false;
4210  }
4211  }
4212  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
4213  {
4214  return approx(static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer),
4215  rhs.m_value.number_float);
4216  }
4217  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
4218  {
4219  return approx(lhs.m_value.number_float,
4220  static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer));
4221  }
4222  return false;
4223  }
4224 
4225  /*!
4226  @brief comparison: equal
4227 
4228  The functions compares the given JSON value against a null pointer. As the
4229  null pointer can be used to initialize a JSON value to null, a comparison
4230  of JSON value @a v with a null pointer should be equivalent to call
4231  `v.is_null()`.
4232 
4233  @param[in] v JSON value to consider
4234  @return whether @a v is null
4235 
4236  @complexity Constant.
4237 
4238  @liveexample{The example compares several JSON types to the null pointer.
4239  ,operator__equal__nullptr_t}
4240  */
4241  friend bool operator==(const_reference v, std::nullptr_t) noexcept
4242  {
4243  return v.is_null();
4244  }

4304  /*!
4305  @brief comparison: less than
4306 
4307  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than another JSON value @a
4308  rhs according to the following rules:
4309  - If @a lhs and @a rhs have the same type, the values are compared using
4310  the default `<` operator.
4311  - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
4312  comparison
4313  - In case @a lhs and @a rhs have different types, the values are ignored
4314  and the order of the types is considered, see
4315  @ref operator<(const value_t, const value_t).
4316 
4317  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
4318  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
4319  @return whether @a lhs is less than @a rhs
4320 
4321  @complexity Linear.
4322 
4323  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
4324  types.,operator__less}
4325  */
4326  friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
4327  {
4328  const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
4329  const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
4330 
4331  if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
4332  {
4333  switch (lhs_type)
4334  {
4335  case (value_t::array):
4336  return *lhs.m_value.array < *rhs.m_value.array;
4337  case (value_t::object):
4338  return *lhs.m_value.object < *rhs.m_value.object;
4339  case (value_t::null):
4340  return false;
4341  case (value_t::string):
4342  return *lhs.m_value.string < *rhs.m_value.string;
4343  case (value_t::boolean):
4344  return lhs.m_value.boolean < rhs.m_value.boolean;
4345  case (value_t::number_integer):
4346  return lhs.m_value.number_integer < rhs.m_value.number_integer;
4347  case (value_t::number_float):
4348  return lhs.m_value.number_float < rhs.m_value.number_float;
4349  case (value_t::discarded):
4350  return false;
4351  }
4352  }
4353  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
4354  {
4355  return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) <
4356  rhs.m_value.number_float;
4357  }
4358  else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
4359  {
4360  return lhs.m_value.number_float <
4361  static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer);
4362  }
4363 
4364  // We only reach this line if we cannot compare values. In that case,
4365  // we compare types. Note we have to call the operator explicitly,
4366  // because MSVC has problems otherwise.
4367  return operator<(lhs_type, rhs_type);
4368  }
4369 
4370  /*!
4371  @brief comparison: less than or equal
4372 
4373  Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than or equal to another
4374  JSON value by calculating `not (rhs < lhs)`.
4375 
4376  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider
4377  @param[in] rhs second JSON value to consider
4378  @return whether @a lhs is less than or equal to @a rhs
4379 
4380  @complexity Linear.
4381 
4382  @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
4383  types.,operator__greater}
4384  */
4385  friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
4386  {
4387  return not (rhs < lhs);
4388  }
4389

4396  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider

4403  types.,operator__lessequal}

4410  /*!

4415 
4416  @param[in] lhs first JSON value to consider

4440  /*!
4441  @brief serialize to stream
4442 
4443  Serialize the given JSON value @a j to the output stream @a o. The JSON
4444  value will be serialized using the @ref dump member function. The
4445  indentation of the output can be controlled with the member variable
4446  `width` of the output stream @a o. For instance, using the manipulator
4447  `std::setw(4)` on @a o sets the indentation level to `4` and the
4448  serialization result is the same as calling `dump(4)`.
4449 
4450  @param[in,out] o stream to serialize to
4451  @param[in] j JSON value to serialize
4452 
4453  @return the stream @a o
4454 
4455  @complexity Linear.
4456 
4457  @liveexample{The example below shows the serialization with different
4458  parameters to `width` to adjust the indentation level.,operator_serialize}
4459  */

4461  {

4463  const bool pretty_print = (o.width() > 0);
4464  const auto indentation = (pretty_print ? o.width() : 0);
4465 
4466  // reset width to 0 for subsequent calls to this stream
4467  o.width(0);
4468 
4469  // do the actual serialization
4470  j.dump(o, pretty_print, static_cast<unsigned int>(indentation));
4471  return o;
4472  }
